bestBHT.bht: Treating these little ones with care pays off, as noted by one source, which draws a connection to the admonition against causing others to stumble. Another source highlights the grave consequences, describing the imagery of being violently hurled into the sea with a millstone. Ultimately, prioritizing the well-being of weaker believers proves profitable, underscoring the importance of considering their welfare.

Henry Alford: 2.] See Matt. xviii. 6, 7, and notes. these little ones] Perhaps the publicans and sinners of ch. xv. 1; perhaps also, repeated with reference to what took place, Matt. 1. c.
Marvin Vincent: It were better [λυσιτελει]. The verb means to pay what is due, and is equivalent to our phrase, it pays.
The correct reading here is liqov mulikov, a millstone; not a great millstone as Matthew.
Thrown [ερριπται]. Hurled: with an underlying sense of violence, called out by so great an outrage.
Philip Schaff: Luke 17:2. Gain. Peculiar to Luke. The reference to the effect of the behavior of the Pharisees is sustained by the mention of little ones.
Archibald T. Robertson: It were well for him... It is profitable for him."
If a millstone were hanged... It is a first-class condition, determined as fulfilled."
Were thrown... all three verbs vivid and expressive.
John Gill: It were better for him that a millstone,....

bhtAttempts.bht: It pays to treat these little ones with care, suggests one commentary, noting the connection to earlier teachings about not causing others to stumble. Another commentary emphasizes the intensity and violence implied by the phrase hurled into the sea with a millstone, emphasizing the severity of the consequences. Ultimately, it is profitable to take the welfare of weaker believers seriously, for their well-being should be a priority.
